awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A fractional-order computational platform for the multiscale and multiphysics analysis of failure-critical systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop the foundation of a fractional-calculus-based computational platform for the simulation of multiscale and multiphysics systems. This Phase I effort will focus on developing modeling capabilities for nonlinear thermomechanical fatigue and damage behavior of ductile materials and will provide important insights on both feasibility and performance of the fractional calculus approach for a class of nonlinear problems that is not only of extreme importance for scientific and industrial applications but it is also a prototypical example of multiscale and multiphysics systems.
By leveraging an advanced and generalized class of operators, namely the distributed and variable-order fractional operators, this project will develop fatigue and damage mechanics simulation software capable of continuum scale computational efficiency and microscale accuracy. The resulting formulation will offer an unprecedented combination of computational efficiency, a high degree of fidelity and accuracy, and a revolutionary adaptive mathematical structure that evolves in real-time based on the underlying physics controlling the deterioration and damage process.

The overarching innovation at the basis of the M3SIM software products is a one-of-its-kind computational platform based on cutting-edge distributed-variable order (DVO) fractional calculus (FC). The unique nature of DVO operators allows the new platform to perform multiscale and multiphysics analyses of complex systems at a level of accuracy and efficiency that is unattainable with traditional methods. This new approach will have profound practical implications for predictive science because it will enable a novel concept of an adaptive computational platform whose structure evolves with the underlying physics without a priori and ad hoc decisions from the user.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This SBIR Phase I project assessed the feasibility of developing a one-of-its-kind, multiscale and multiphysics mechanics computational platform based on fractional calculus. The unique properties and capabilities of the fractional operators can allow the new platform to perform multiscale and multiphysics analyses of complex mechanical systems at a level of accuracy and sensitivity largely beyond traditional methods. More specifically, this Phase I research focused on developing computational capabilities in the area of degradation of materials operating under thermomechanical loading.

The ability to reliably predict material degradation, damage initiation, and structural failure is of critical importance for most Original Equipment Manufacturers (across the aerospace, mechanical, civil, and biomedical engineering sectors) in order to ensure products’ safety, reduce maintenance costs, improve performance, and even enable futuristic products for which testing might not be readily accessible (e.g. space transportation systems and extraterrestrial habitats). By streamlining the design process and reducing the current need for prototyping and reliability testing, this technology can lead to safer and more reliable products at a significantly lower cost for both manufacturers and consumers.

The work conducted under Phase I achieved some important objectives. First, the problem of thermomechanical material degradation was mathematically formulated via the proposed approach and implemented in a computational code. Second, the code was exercised to generate a series of numerical simulations reproducing benchmark problems for which experimental data are available in the literature. This step was critical to provide a preliminary experimental validation of the concept as well as to confirm its feasibility. Finally, the remaining activities focused on the preliminary design and development of the necessary software infrastructure that includes pre- and post-processing tools as well as the proper documentation for both user and developers.

This work led to key conclusions. From a general perspective, the theoretical and numerical results supported the initial assumptions at the basis of the Phase I research and the comparison with experimental data conclusively proved the feasibility of the fractional mechanics approach for material degradation. Collectively, results provided all the necessary data to support transition towards Phase II and indicated a preferred path towards an effective technology transfer and a successful product development.


Last Modified: 02/29/2024
Modified by: Sansit Patnaik
